title: Virtual Luminary Event: Meet the Curators
short_description: Get to know Art Institute curators Lisa Ayla Çakmak and Yeonsoo Chee as they share paintings that remind them of childhood, discuss whom they would like to paint their portraits, and explore the collection objects they are most looking forward to working with.
list_description: Get to know Art Institute curators Lisa Ayla Çakmak and Yeonsoo Chee.
description:
Join us for a Luminary member exclusive event featuring Lisa Çakmak, chair and curator of Arts of the Ancient Mediterranean and Byzantium, and Yeonsoo Chee, associate curator of Korean art. Get to know the curators who have joined the Art Institute of Chicago this year as they share paintings that remind them of childhood, discuss whom they would like to paint their portraits, and explore the collection objects they are most looking forward to working with.

This event is exclusive to Luminary members and advance registration is required. Space is limited to give you the best experience possible. To register, email luminary@artic.edu. Details and instructions on how to join the Zoom meeting will be emailed in advance of the event.

Questions? Please reach out to us at luminary@artic.edu.

ABOUT THE PANELISTS

Lisa Çakmak joined the Art Institute of Chicago this past summer as chair of Arts of the Ancient Mediterranean and Byzantium, where she plans to engage especially with Etruscan, Greek, Roman, and Byzantine art. She previously served as the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation Associate Curator at the Saint Louis Art Museum, where her work included spearheading acclaimed special exhibitions and overseeing the reinstallation of the Greek and Roman art galleries as well as the collections of Egyptian art and ancient coins. She has participated in excavations at Tel Kedesh, Israel and published on this excavation's findings. She earned her AB from Princeton University, PhD from University of Michigan, and MBA from Washington University in St. Louis.

Yeonsoo Chee became associate curator of Korean Art this past spring, working in the Arts of Asia Department to help build the collection of works from Korea and support the goal of representing the expanse of art across the Asian continent. She has worked as a curator and director of exhibitions at the National Palace Museum of Korea in Seoul. Previously, her work at the USC Pacific Asia Museum in Los Angeles included developing programs, growing the collection, and overseeing reinstallation of the galleries of Korean art. She earned her BA in English Language and Literature from Ewha Womans University in Seoul and her BA in Asian art history and MA in Korean art history from California State University Long Beach, where she also completed the Museum Studies program.
